abstract.p: Howard Goldberg reviews 1999 Muga white Rioja wine from Rioja Alta region of Spain and 1999 Borsao red; photo (M)

This week La Caravelle, the three-star Manhattan restaurant, bought '99 Muga white Rioja to sell by the glass, a tipoff that the producer has fielded a winner.

Bodegas Muga, in the Rioja Alta region, is one of Spain's few traditionalists still rearing its wines wholly in oak. Indeed, an agreeably woody bouquet and flavor frame this barrel-fermented composition of native viura grapes with some malvasia.

Fans of barrel-fermented California chardonnay are likely to be wooed by the vanillan, almost baked-apple aroma with its hints of smoked meat, the wine's ample body and creamy texture, the almost honeyed flavor, the roundness.

For optimum use, chill this bright, pale-brass-colored dry wine moderately and then, in the (alas, too often studied) manner of aficionados, keep swirling and sniffing it so that convection currents keep releasing its subtleties.

If this blanco accompanies a fish course, the meat course will find a friend in '99 Borsao Red Wine, a simple, fleshy, fruity brew, which manages to be smooth and gutsy. This is a solid, consoling wine for a Tuesday night, when you walk off Metro-North washed out, not Saturday's dinner party, when A-list Burgundy takes over.

Seventy-five percent garnacha (grenache) grapes give the blend a Rhone inflection; 25 percent tempranillo, its Iberian hue. Agricola de Borja in the Campo de Borja appellation in Zaragoza province, in northeastern Spain, is the producer.

Wine Connection, 71 Westchester Avenue, Pound Ridge, asks $12 for Muga, $7 for Borsao. Green Lane, 741 Bedford Road, Bedford Hills, charges $11 for Muga and (a best buy) $5 for Borsao. Edras, 513 Boston Post Road, Port Chester, gets $7 for Borsao.
Both wines are available to merchants at Tempranillo, the importer, in Mamaroneck.
